chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of tiredness/fatigue in adults
chapter.summary: Covers the primary care management of adults with tiredness/fatigue.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 18 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer an adult with tiredness/fatigue?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange referral to an appropriate secondary care specialist if there is a suspected or confirmed underlying cause that cannot be managed in primary care.
  • Arrange referral to a specialist chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) service for possible cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) and/or graded exercise therapy (planned increases in the duration of physical activity), if CFS diagnostic criteria are met:
    • Immediately, if symptoms are severe.
    • Within 3–4 months of presentation, if symptoms are moderate.
    • Within 6 months of presentation, if symptoms are mild.
  • Consider arranging referral to an appropriate specialist if there is persistent, unexplained tiredness/fatigue which does not meet the diagnostic criteria for CFS, if:
    • There is significant uncertainty regarding the presence of an underlying physical cause.
    • The person would benefit from the reassurance of a second opinion or from a thorough specialist secondary care evaluation, and referral is not likely to reinforce unrealistic beliefs in a physical cause.
    • The person may benefit from access to the care delivered by a specialist CFS service.
    • A secondary care opinion is required for occupational reasons, or for assessment of eligibility for disability benefits.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on referral are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Chronic fatigue syndrome/myalgic encephalomyelitis (or encephalopathy): diagnosis and management of CFS/ME in adults and children [NICE, 2007], two Cochrane systematic reviews Cognitive behaviour therapy for chronic fatigue syndrome in adults [Price, 2008], and Exercise therapy for chronic fatigue syndrome [Larun, 2019], a US systematic review of CFS treatments [Smith, 2015], and expert opinion in a review article on investigating unexplained fatigue [Bansal, 2016].

Arranging referral to an appropriate specialist
  • The recommendation to refer a person to an appropriate secondary care specialist if an underlying cause for fatigue cannot be managed in primary care is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Arranging referral to a specialist chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) service
  • The recommendations to arrange referral to a specialist CFS service and the appropriate timescales for referral, for possible cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) and/or graded exercise therapy (GET), are largely based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2007].
    • NICE highlights that any decision to refer should be based on their needs, the type, duration, complexity, and severity of their symptoms, and the presence of comorbidities.
    • NICE recommends an individualised, person-centred programme should be offered to people with CFS to maintain or ideally gradually extend their physical, emotional, and cognitive capacity, and to help manage the impact of symptoms.
    • A NICE evidence review found that CBT and/or GET should be offered to people with mild or moderate CFS, as these interventions show the clearest research evidence of benefit.
  • A Cochrane systematic review of 15 randomized controlled trials (RCTs; n = 1043 adults) found that CBT was effective at reducing symptoms of fatigue compared with usual care, and may be more effective than other psychological therapies (relaxation, counselling, and education/support). The findings at follow up were based on a small number of studies and were inconsistent, such that the duration of any benefit from CBT was unclear [Price, 2008].
  • A Cochrane systematic review of eight RCTs (n = 1,518 adults) on the effects of exercise therapy for CFS found that this intervention probably has a positive effect on fatigue compared with usual care or 'passive therapies'. Control groups included people undertaking CBT, adaptive pacing, and taking antidepressant therapy. Owing to limited evidence, it was difficult to draw conclusions on the effectiveness of alternative interventions [Larun, 2019].
  • A US systematic review of 35 treatment trials found low- to moderate-quality evidence that counselling therapy and GET compared with no treatment, relaxation, or support improved outcomes of fatigue, function, global improvement, and fitness for work in some trials; counselling therapy also improved quality of life outcomes. The authors noted the included studies were heterogenous regarding study size, duration, applicability, and methodological quality [Smith, 2015].
Considering arranging specialist referral
  • The recommendation on when to consider referral for people with persistent, unexplained tiredness/fatigue not meeting the criteria for a diagnosis of CFS is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice. This approach is supported by the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage an adult with tiredness/fatigue in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
For all people with persistent tiredness/fatigue not needing referral to a specialist (or people with suspected chronic fatigue syndrome [CFS] who are awaiting specialist assessment):

  • Manage any underlying causes and contributory factors, as identified on initial assessment.
    • Offer an understandable explanation for tiredness/fatigue that provides links between psychosocial and physical factors.
  • Offer advice on sources of information and support, if relevant, such as:
    • The patient information leaflet Tiredness (fatigue) available on the www.patient.info.
    • The NHS information leaflet Sleep and tiredness.
    • The Action for ME (website available at www.actionforme.org.uk) booklet Newly diagnosed with ME/CFS.
  • Manage any associated stress, anxiety, and/or depression. See the CKS topics on Generalized anxiety disorder, Depression, and Post-traumatic stress disorder for more information.
  • Offer advice on sleep hygiene, including trying to avoid excessive sleep, and daytime sleeping or naps. See the CKS topic on Insomnia for more information.
  • Offer lifestyle advice including:
    • Limiting the length of rest periods to 30 minutes at a time.
    • Introducing low level physical and cognitive activities (depending on the severity of symptoms).
    • Avoiding unsupervised or unstructured vigorous exercise.
    • Using relaxation techniques, such as guided visualisation and breathing techniques.
    • Eating a healthy, balanced diet.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of tiredness/fatigue in primary care are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Chronic fatigue syndrome/myalgic encephalomyelitis (or encephalopathy): diagnosis and management of CFS/ME in adults and children [NICE, 2007], the Canadian Toward Optimized Practice (TOP) clinical practice guideline summary [TOP, 2016], a questionnaire-based study of fatigue and its associations [Engberg, 2017], a Swiss population-based cross-sectional survey [Galland-Decker, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles on investigating unexplained fatigue [Bansal, 2016] and on chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) [Fukuda, 1994].

Managing any underlying causes and contributory factors
  • The NICE clinical guideline notes that advice on symptom management should not be delayed until a diagnosis of CFS is established. Advice should be tailored to the specific symptoms the person has and be aimed at minimizing the impact on daily activities [NICE, 2007]. Furthermore, expert opinion in a review article notes that a suspected diagnosis of CFS should not delay treatment of coexisting disorders, such as depression [Fukuda, 1994].
  • The recommendation to identify and manage any underlying and contributing factors is extrapolated from expert opinion in review articles [Fukuda, 1994; Bansal, 2016].
Offering advice on sources of information and support
  • This recommendation is extrapolated from the NICE clinical guideline that advises to offer information about local and national self-help groups and support groups for people with CFS and their carers [NICE, 2007].
Managing any associated stress, anxiety, and/or depression
  • This recommendation is largely based on the NICE clinical guideline that recommends management of comorbid stress and anxiety [NICE, 2007].
  • This approach is supported by the TOP guideline summary that recommends management of associated mood disorders and anxiety for people with suspected CFS [TOP, 2016] and expert opinion in a review article [Bansal, 2016].
Offering advice on sleep hygiene
  • This recommendation is extrapolated from the NICE clinical guideline, which notes that sleep management advice is important including to avoid daytime sleeping and naps [NICE, 2007].
    • It notes that people with CFS should be advised that excessive sleep does not generally improve physical or mental functioning, and excessive periods of daytime sleep or frequent napping may further disrupt the sleep-wake cycle.
Offering lifestyle advice
  • The NICE clinical guideline recommends giving lifestyle advice on rest periods, activities, healthy diet, and relaxation techniques that may also help pain management and sleep problems. NICE did not find good evidence for the benefits or harms of pacing of activities [NICE, 2007].
  • The TOP guideline summary recommends sleep hygiene, effective pain management, pacing cognitive tasks similar to pacing physical activity (identifying a person's energy at a given time and adapting activity level to energy level), and planning important tasks for the 'best time of day'. It also recommends avoiding high-intensity or multisensory situations or events [TOP, 2016].
  • A questionnaire-based cross-sectional study in Sweden (n = 1557 adults) exploring the four categories of general fatigue, physical fatigue, reduced activity, and mental fatigue, concluded that interventions increasing physical exercise and reducing sedentary behaviour may be important to help people with fatigue [Engberg, 2017].
  • A Swiss population-based cross-sectional survey concluded that measures to reduce fatigue should include advice to improve sleep quantity and quality, and manage depression. In addition, preventive measures such as stress management and health promotion, like relaxation, time management, and 'cognitive reframing', may improve sleep quality, improve self-rated health, and reduce fatigue levels [Galland-Decker, 2019].
  • Expert opinion in a review article notes that CFS therapies include nutritional supplements, adaptive pacing, graded exercise therapy (GET), deep relaxation using different approaches, and psychological therapy including cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT). It recommends combinations of pacing of daily physical and mental activity to prevent relapsing-remitting fatigue, a healthy balanced diet, and appropriate sleep hygiene [Bansal, 2016].
